1.title: Unknown Lady
1.sitter_text: Unknown Lady (perhaps of the Vavasour family)
1.description_content: Isaac Oliver's portrait of a fashionably attired unknown lady depicts a young, stylishly attired woman, with a black hat and a profusion of white lace and pearls. She has long been considered a ‘typical’ example of this artist's work.
1.description_physical:
The ultraviolet (UV) image of this work shows that numerous areas have been retouched. These include portions of her hat and black costume, which display a greenish fluorescence under UV illumination, indicative of the presence of modern pigments, such as zinc white (as confirmed by additional X-ray fluorescence [XRF] analysis). Extensive repainting can also be identified throughout the white passages of the costume.

The white overpainting appears to be covering dull grey (original) paint, whose muted colour must have been the reason for the extensive intervention. This grey pigment has been identified as calomel, which was probably white initially, but exposure to light or possibly alkali turned it grey, thus making necessary the extensive repainting.
1.pigments_costume: Dress: bone black, lead white, vermilion, bone black (retouching), zinc white (retouching), indigo (retouching); lace: calomel/mercury white (retouch: barium sulphate); ruff:  barium sulphate (retouching), calcium-based compound (retouching)
1.pigments_flesh_tones_and_lips: Flesh tones: lead white, vermilion, red lead; lips: red lead, vermilion, pink lake
1.pigments_hair_and_beard: Carbon-based black, red lead, lead white, yellow earth pigments

56.title: Jane Boughton, née Coningsby (b. 1553)
56.description_physical:
The palette identified is compatible with the materials available to Hilliard.
UV image: the flesh tone appears bright white, due to the fluorescence of the parchment underneath; the orange UV fluorescence colour is associated to the use of lead white. 
The verso of the playing card was analysed: red areas: vermilion; dark and blue areas: indigo; green area: indigo and likely a yellow dye; yellow areas: yellow dye(?); purple areas: red/ purple dye(?)

56.pigments_hair_and_beard: Earth pigment, chalk, lead-tin yellow, carbon black
56.pigments_jewellery: Silver; gold (orange underlayer: earth pigments and arsenic sulphides)

63.title: Portrait of William Drummond of Hawthornden (c. 1615)
63.description_physical:
The UV image shows limited retouching on the white ruff and flesh areas: the retouching appears bright yellow in UV which is usually associated with the presence of zinc white. The dull orange UV fluorescence colour evident on the ruff is instead due to the use of lead white, and is original. A dark red/maroon UV fluorescence colour on the background is likely due to the use of a red lake and indigo.

The x-ray image highlights the wood grain of the support onto which the miniature is laid. 
This image is also particularly useful in this case because it reveals the presence of an upside-down heart  in the area of the sitter's face. This symbol is present on the playing card, the back of which remains inaccessible due to the framing of this object. The MA-XRF analysis suggests that this heart was executed using vermilion.
63.pigments_costume: Doublet: bone black, carbon black, lead white; white ruff: lead white, azurite (shading), zinc white (retouching)
63.pigments_flesh_tones_and_lips: Flesh tones: lead white, chalk, red lead(?), earth pigment(?), barium white (retouching); lips: red lake, red lead(?)
63.pigments_hair_and_beard: Earth and umber pigments, chalk, lead-based pigment, lead-tin yellow, carbon black(?)

65.title: George Clifford (1558-1605), 3rd Earl of Cumberland, Admiral
65.sitter_text: George Clifford (1558-1605), 3rd Earl of Cumberland, Admiral
65.description_physical:
The raking light image shows the floating-in technique used to paint the background around the sitter's figure. Under UV, the miniature seems to be in a good state of preservation, with some colour losses around the border, which appear bright white due to the fluorescence of the parchment. The orange UV fluorescence displayed by the collar suggests the use of lead white in this area, whereas the pinkish colour of the lips indicates the presence of a red organic dye.
The blue background appears dark in the NIR image, due to the use of a copper-based pigment (azurite), as well as the black doublet and hat due to the presence of carbon-based black pigments. A faint hatching is evident around the border of the background, likely made with a different blue pigment.
The flesh tones are painted with a small amount of lead white, as evident in the x-ray image because they appear dark. The doublet and hat also appear dark, but the modelling with lead white is evident in the doublet, which appear moderately grey.
65.pigments_costume: Black doublet: bone black, lead white; white collar: lead white, azurite; black hat: bone black, carbon black
65.pigments_flesh_tones_and_lips: Flesh tones: lead white, red lead(?), vermilion (for outlining the features); lips: red lead(?)
65.pigments_hair_and_beard: Earth pigment, carbon black(?), lead white(?)

66.title: George Clifford (1558-1605), 3rd Earl of Cumberland, Admiral
66.sitter_text: George Clifford (1558-1605), 3rd Earl of Cumberland, Admiral
66.description_physical:
The raking light shows the floating-in technique for the background, applied around the sitter's head and beard. Some colour losses are evident around the border. 
Under UV, the collar, costume and small details in the eyes show a bright red UV fluorescence, characteristic of mercury white. The miniature appears retouched around the border, especially at the top and left side, and on the sash area; the bright yellow UV fluorescence suggests the use of zinc white.
Blue and green areas appear dark in the NIR image, suggesting the use of copper-based pigments. In particular, the retouched areas in the background are distinguishable from the original paint passage because they appear darker; one single area at the top left is transparent to the IR radiation, indicating a different blue pigment from the one used for the original background or the repainting.
The flesh tones are painted with a small amount of lead white, as evident from the x-ray image and the dark area corresponding to flesh tones and hair. An heavy element, identified by XRF as mercury, is used in the costume, collar and eyes, which appear white. Part of the costume is black because it was left unpainted, and brushstrokes of white pigments are roughly applied. The background and sash also appear moderately white, due to the use of copper in this case. Colour losses appearing dark are evident in the background and around the border.
66.pigments_costume: Doublet: lead white, calomel/mercury white; blue flowers: azurite; orange flowers: red lead; pink flowers: red lake; green leaves: mineral copper green, yellow dye(?); deep blue sash: azurite, red organic dye; collar: lead white, calomel/mercury white
66.pigments_flesh_tones_and_lips: Flesh tones: lead white, red lead, vermilion; lips: red lead(?)
66.pigments_hair_and_beard: Earth pigment, calomel/vermilion, lead-based pigment, carbon black(?)

84.title: Anne of Denmark
84.description_physical:
Some details in the hair ornaments, brooches and pendant contain brass.
Under UV light, the miniature appears heavily retouched. Areas with a yellow-green UV fluorescence, such as the pearls and portions of the ruff, are retouched with zinc white. Orange parts are lead white retouchings?? 
The red background has a reddish UV fluorescence, characterisc of red lakes. 
Green and blue areas appear dark in the NIR image, suggesting the use of copper-based pigments. The shaded area of the ruff is also dark to the NIR radiation, likely due to the use of carbon black to shade the portion.
The x-ray highlights the use of metals and lead-based pigments (lead white and red lead), which appear bright in the image. The flesh tones are painted with only a small amount of lead white.
84.pigments_costume: Dress: lead white, copper sulphate, azurite; orange ribbon: red lead, red lake; pink ribbon: pink lake, vermilion; white collar: lead white, zinc white (retouching)
84.pigments_flesh_tones_and_lips: Flesh tones: lead white, red lead(?), pink dye (modelling on the cheeks); lips: red lead(?), pink lake
84.pigments_jewellery: Gold; silver; blue cross pendant: azurite, zinc white (retouching), barium white (retouching), Prussian blue (retouching), brass

85.title: Charles I as a Child, King of England Scotland and Ireland
85.description_physical:
Under UV and raking light, the miniature appears in a good state of preservation, and no retouchings are evident. The red background and pink lips show a reddish UV fluorescence, indicating the use of red lakes. White areas that appear orange under UV, such as the collar and eyes, are painted with lead white.
Blue and green areas appear dark in the NIR region, suggesting the presence of copper-based pigments. The shading part of the collar also appears dark, indicating the use of carbon black to make this area grey.
The x-ray image highlights the use of heavy elements, such as lead, that appear brighter. A round shape painted with an heavy element, identified with XRF as mercury, is also evident at the centre of the miniature, but it belongs to the playing card used as support. The flesh tones and hair appear painted with a very small amount of lead-based pigments.
The vermilion distribution linked to the playing card could suggest that a figure card was used.
85.pigments_costume: White and green doublet: lead white, carbon black (shading), copper-based green (sulphate?), lead-tin yellow (layer under green); blue ribbon: azurite, ultramarine; white collar: lead white, azurite, carbon black (grey area)
85.pigments_flesh_tones_and_lips: Flesh tones: lead white, red lead(?), red earth pigment (outlines of the facial features); lips: red lead, red dye
85.pigments_hair_and_beard: Earth pigments, carbon black(?), lead white(?)
